node.title: Cook Strait ferry services disrupted due to Covid-19, maintenance delays
node.description: High demand and a shortage of vessels are putting pressure on Cook Strait ferry services this Easter weekend and into next month. Audio

node.title: 'We sense a bit of a thrill aspect here': Police concern over teens doing ram raids
node.description: The majority of those carrying out ram raids around the country were 17 or younger, latest police figures show. Audio

node.title: British PM Boris Johnson fined by police over lockdown parties
node.description: Boris Johnson has been fined by the police for attending a birthday party thrown for him during a Covid-19 lockdown.

node.title: Auckland man can be extradited to China, Supreme Court rules
node.description: Kyung Yup Kim is accused of killing a woman in Shanghai in 2009 but denies any involvement. The Chinese government called for his extradition in 2011 and he now can be.

node.title: Greens oppose move to orange, looser mask rules at schools
node.description: Opposition parties are pleased New Zealand will move to the orange traffic light tonight, but Labour's partner party is not so supportive.

node.title: Police investigating after fatality at a workplace in Gisborne
node.description: A man has died following a workplace incident at Awapuni in Gisborne.

node.title: Reserve Bank lifts OCR to 1.5 percent
node.description: The Reserve Bank has stepped up the battle against inflation with an increase of half of a percentage point in the Official Cash Rate to 1.5 percent, with a warning that further rises are coming. Audio

node.title: Drugs running out, surgeries cancelled as Sri Lanka's health system buckles
node.description: Sri Lanka's healthcare system is close to collapse under the weight an economic crisis in the island nation with shortages of vital drugs and hospitals suspending some procedures and tests.

node.title: Montoya banned for four games for homophobic slur
node.description: Warriors winger Marcelo Montoya has been suspended for four NRL games for the on-field use of a homophobic slur.

node.title: NZ banks' quarterly profit soar to $1.6b as expenses slashed
node.description: The country's banking sector ended last year with record profits, but the outlook looks tougher.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 9495 new community cases, a further 15 deaths
node.description: There are 9495 new community cases of Covid-19 along with a further 15 deaths to report today.

node.title: Pence decries cancel culture amid protests, praises Zelenskyy at University of Virginia
node.description: Pence faced protests from students upset with his past rhetoric towards LGBTQ communities.

node.title: Two charged with murder of Gisborne woman Maraea Smith
node.description: Two people have been charged with the murder of a Gisborne woman nearly three weeks ago.

node.title: Covid-19: Government offers $9m for pandemic research
node.description: Health Minister Andrew Little announced the funding this morning saying New Zealand needed to build on what had been learnt over the past two years.

node.title: Spate of car thefts in Bay of Plenty and Waikato by youth - police
node.description: Police are encouraging car owners to take precautions after a spate of thefts across the wider Bay of Plenty and Waikato areas.

node.title: Elon Musk accused of illegally delaying disclosure of Twitter shares
node.description: The complaint accuses Musk of violating a regulatory deadline, allowing him to continue buying shares at a cheaper price.

node.title: Trustpower warns of cash flow pressures as it develops new projects
node.description: Trustpower shareholders are in for a windfall as it sells its retail arm, but the company is warning of some cash flow pressure ahead.

node.title: 'A pandemic is not the way to tackle climate change'
node.description: Climate Change Minister James Shaw says the latest report shows we cannot rely on a pandemic to cut emissions, and National's Christopher Luxon says more may need to be done.

node.title: Food price annual increase highest in over 10 years
node.description: Food prices were 7.6 percent higher in March than the year before - the biggest annual increase since the year ended July 2011.

node.title: "Nobody will ever be able to fill the shoes of Tā Toby"
node.description: After 16 years, the chair of the Te Arawa Lakes Trust, Sir Toby Curtis, has decided to step down.

node.title: Queenstown Lakes mayor Jim Boult not standing for re-election
node.description: Boult has served two terms as mayor since winning election in 2016 and says the decision came after lengthy consideration and discussions with his family,

node.title: Marsden Point refinery protest scales back
node.description: The organiser of a protest outside the former Marsden Point oil refinery insists anti-vax campaigners have left.

node.title: 'The sea level is not going to rise so don't worry about it'
node.description: A Westport Rating Joint Committee discussion on the town's proposed flood protection scheme has prompted regional council chairman Allan Birchfield to claim "the sea level is not going to rise so…

node.title: Trading halt placed on King Salmon ahead of full year result release
node.description: Marlborough-based King Salmon has been placed in a trading halt ahead of the scheduled release of its full year result and a potential capital raising.

node.title: Sherri Papini admits to faking her 2016 kidnapping
node.description: "I am deeply ashamed of myself for my behavior," Papini said in a statement.

node.title: 'Stupid and uneducated' ruling: ACC may not cover public holiday wages
node.description: An overhaul of the Holidays Act has thrown up a new, curly problem that could cost employers.

node.title: Backers defend plans for offshore wind energy project off Taranaki coast
node.description: The backers of a new wind energy project off the Taranaki coast believe the eyewatering costs of their technology will come down by the time work starts - that is if it goes ahead.

node.title: Commercial landlord gives tenant one-star review over vax passes
node.description: An Auckland bar that has continued to use vaccine passes has received a one star Facebook review from its own landlord.

node.title: Gisborne flooding partially closes State Highway 35
node.description: Flooding in the Gisborne region has closed State Highway 35 in two places between Hicks Bay and Te Araroa, and between Tokomaru Bay and Te Puia Springs. Audio

node.title: Diabetes and me: Making sustainable changes
node.description: My health is maybe not something I can fix in three months but if it isn't something I am being graded on, how will I know I have done well? RNZ's Megan Whelan shares her journey of learning to live…
